Paula is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase more raw materials. This will be her second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw materials to manufacture additional products

loans.name: Gulbahor

texts.en:
M. Gulbahor is 39 years old. She is married with three children. To help her husband support the family, Gulbahor is running her own business. She sells jewelry and has been in this business for more than 5 years. Today, Gulbahor is requesting $2,700 US Dollars. She is planning to purchase new items of jewelry like earrings, rings, bracelets and chains to expand her product range. This is her fourth loan and she promises to observe all the procedures concerning the payment of the loan as she did with her previous loans.  

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes being a key post along the Silk Road and marking the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. Even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to purchase new products for resale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more red oil, pepper, onions and salt

loans.name: Héléna

texts.fr: Y. est une femme âgée et dynamique, elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu la vente de bouillie faite à base de farine de blé accompagné de galette et elle vend également du jus, elle travaille les matins et les soirs car les matins les gens consomment de la bouillie pour le petit déjeuner. elle voudrait s'approvisionner pour dynamiser son activité raison pour laquelle elle sollicite du crédit pour l'achat de  2 sacs de farine de blé, 2 sacs de sucre, 4 bidons d'huile et un congélateur. sa clientèle se compose de toutes personnes.
texts.en:
Héléna is an energetic elderly woman. In order to earn a living, she sells "bouillie" (a type of porridge) made from wheat flour along with "galette" (a sort of pancake). She also sells juice. She works mornings and evenings because people eat porridge in the morning for breakfast. She would like to stock up to boost her business. As a result, she is requesting a loan to buy 2 sacks of wheat flour, 2 sacks of sugar, 4 cans of oil and a freezer. Her customer base is made up of all types of people.

Translated from French by Marie-Elodie Bazy, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase food products

loans.name: S. Euphrasie Irma

texts.fr: A. S. Euphrasie Irma est née le 14 Mars 1965 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Irma est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Irma est une veuve, qui vit donc seule avec ses enfants au quartier Agbodjèdo à Cotonou, depuis un an. Irma n’a jamais fréquenté l’école. Pour assurer ses besoins et répondre aux différents besoins de ses enfants, Irma vend de la friperie depuis une quinzaine d’année. Irma achète ses produits à Missèbo, un marché de Cotonou, et les revend dans le même marché. C’est la deuxième fois que Irma sollicite auprès de ALIDé, un crédit, en vue de renforcer son activité et d’augmenter sa clientèle et son chiffre d’affaire. Irma a bien effectué le remboursement du premier crédit.
texts.en:
S. Euphrasie Irma A. was born on March 14, 1965 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Irma has three children, all of whom go to school. Irma is a widow; she has been living alone with her children at the Agbodjèdo district of Cotonou for about a year. Irma has never been to school. In order to support herself and provide for her children’s needs, Irma has been selling used clothing for about a dozen years. Irma stocks up in Missèbo, a market in Cotonou, and resells her wares a the same market. This is the second time that Irma is seeking a loan from ALIDé in order to bolster her business, increasing her customer base and her revenues. Irma has repaid her first loan well.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing used clothing

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda Cañete earns her living by operating three business ventures: a general store, a chainsaw rental service, and a farming business. Her husband, Sonny Cañete, age 49, works as a chainsaw operator to earn his living and also helps in his wife's business activities. They have 12 children who are between the ages of 8 and 30. The family lives in Gilside, Brgy. Nabulao, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. 

Florenda joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1998 because she aspired toward something better for her family. With the help of her past 13 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Florenda has been working hard and incrementally lifting her family out of poverty. Her previous loan of PHP 6,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 20,000, which helped to improve the family's standard of living. 

This time, for her 14th cycle loan, she is borrowing PHP 18,000, which she intends to use to purchase an expanded inventory for her general store so that she can continue to save up for the future education of her children. Florenda Cañete is truly a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams. 

About NWTF:

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon. Dungganon is a Hiligaynon word that means "honorable." Through this alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass anything they could have imagined. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: To purchase an exapnded inventory for her general store

loans.name: Safina

texts.en: Safina N. lives in the Kyebando neighborhood in Kampala, Uganda.  She is single and has six children, all of whom attend school.  Safina has a business of selling and frying fish.  She has been in this business for over 10 years, and she works seven days a week. Safina sells her products from home.   Safina has requested a loan for  600,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more baskets of fish.  She also generates additional income through poultry farming.   Safina's main business challenges are transportation and the rainy season.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a delivery van and to buy a plot of land.  Safina lives in a home, which she rents; she does not have access to electricity or piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees, rent, and food for her family.

loans.use: To buy more baskets of fish

loans.name: Ramona Palmira

texts.es:
En la ciudadela La California de  Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Rio De Oro.

La señora Ramona  es socia fundadora del Banco Comunal Rio de Oro y le gusta por la ayuda que reciben tanto ella como sus amigas y compañeras del Banco, tiene 47 años de edad, está casada y fruto de esta relación tuvo cinco hijos, todos ya son mayores de edad pero dos de ellos viven aun con ella. El esposo ya es jubilado.

Ella tiene un negocio de cibert café en el cual ofrece servicio de llamadas telefónicas e internet, trabaja todos los días desde las 8am hasta las 21h00, trabaja con la ayuda de tres de sus hijos, que se turnan para atender el negocio.

Este crédito es para arreglar un poco el local ya que le faltan ciertas cosas para poder brindar más comodidad a sus clientes. Su sueño es tener buena salud ella y los suyos.
texts.en:
The members of the 'Rio de Oro' community bank meet every fortnight in La California, in Portoviejo, the capital of Manabí, which has been known for many years as 'the city of the royal tamarind trees'.

Ramona is a founding member of the Rio de Oro community bank and she likes the bank because the help that she receives.  She also likes her friends and fellow bank members.  Ramona is 47 years old.  She is married and has five children from her marriage who are all now grown up.  However, two of her grown-up children still live with her.  Her husband is retired.

Ramona has an Internet café where she offers telephone calls and Internet services.  She works every day from 8.00am to 9.00pm.  She works with the help of three of her children who take turns to serve in the business.

This loan will be used to fix up the premises a little as they lack certain things which they need to make their customers more comfortable.  Ramona's dream is for herself and her family to enjoy good health.

loans.use: To adapt her premises

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar is a resident of a small city named Riwind in Pakistan. Riwind city is famous for its dairy industry. She lives with her family in a two-room house. Kosar is 38 years old, a talented lady, and performs her duty of a seamstress. In order to financially support her family she sews clothes for her neighborhood. She is very good at her work and can sew every designer's clothes, and due to her good work her customers give her regular orders. Her husband’s name is M. A., and he operates a brick-selling business. He purchases bricks from the brickmakers and provides them to his clients for a profit. 

Kosar has given birth to 2 sons and 3 daughters. Her eldest son could not get an education due to the poor financial conditions of his family. He is a tailor by profession and operates a tailoring shop in the market. He learned this art from his mother and now is becoming an expert in his work. 

Kosar has applied for a loan from the Kiva partner Asasah for the improvement of her husband’s business. With the loan her husband will buy bricks in bulk quantity that will cut his cost of purchasing and also enable him fulfilling larger orders on time. 

She is a regular loan user of Asasah and this is her 3rd loan application. In previous loan years, she has maintained a good credit behavior and never missed any meeting. Note: In the photo, the lady who is raising her hand is Kosar.

loans.use: To buy bricks for bricks selling business

loans.name: Maria Francisca

texts.es: Maria Francisca tiene 51 años, su actividad es la venta y elaboración de cazuelas. Hace más de 3 años que tiene este negocio, por lo que siempre está buscando la forma de generar ingresos. Inicio por la necesidad de obtener un trabajo que le generara lo necesario para mantener a sus hijos. El motivo del financiamiento es para la compra de materiales que son necesarios para la elaboración de sus productos.
texts.en: Maria Francisca is 51 years old. She sells and makes saucepans. Maria has had this business for over 3 years, and she is always looking for ways to generate earnings. Maria began the business because she needed to obtain a job that generated the necessary earnings for her to look after her children. The motive for the loan is so purchase the necessary materials so she can make her products.

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ama

texts.en:
Ama T. is married and has five dependents. She pursued her education through senior high school. Ama sells cooked rice in Takoradi, which she has been doing for 15 years. Her husband is a street cleaner. She assists her husband in providing for the family's basic needs. 

Ama plans to use the loan to purchase more rice to cook and sell. With the new profits from her expanded business, Ama plans to educate her dependents.

loans.use: To purchase more rice to cook and sell

loans.name: Bahrom

texts.ru: Сафаров Бахром проживает в городе Куляб. Ему 32 года. Женат. Имеет троих детей. Живет вместе с родителями. Отец работает главным бухгалтером в строительном учреждении. Сам Бахром имеет высшее образование, биолог. Предоставляет услугу, такси. В этой области уже два года. Кредит берет для приобретения новой машины.
texts.en: Bahrom S., 32, lives in Qulyab. He is married with three children and lives with his parents. His father is a chief accountant in a construction company. Bahrom is a university graduate in biology but he makes a living as a taxi driver. Having been in this business for two years, he is applying for a loan in order to purchase a new car.

loans.use: to purchase a new car

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en: Emmanuel is 32 years old, married with two childre living in Hioma Uganda with a dream to educate his children to attain  a degree.He has a drug shop and has been running it for 6 months and  his dreams is to own a pharmacy. He started it with savings he had gotten from his salary and faces a challenge of seasonal variations. He needs the loan for stocking supplies of drugs.

loans.use: Purchase supplies of  drugs.

loans.name: Oa

texts.en: Oa H. has been a farming businesswoman for a long time. She lives the province of Kompong Cham. Oa H. has owned and operated her farm  cultivating a rice crops from which she earns daily revenue. Oa H., 77, is a widowed mother who has given birth to five children, one is married, and four are single. One of her single children is working in garment factory. Oa H.’s daughter says that it is very difficult for her to travel to work because she doesn’t have a vehicle, and she goes to work by hiring motor taxi. To resolve this situation, Oa H. is asking for a loan to buy a second-hand motorcycle for her daughter to ride to her working place.

loans.use: To buy a secondhand motorbike for her daughter to ride to work.

loans.name: Laurita

texts.en:
Laurita is a 56-year-old married woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures:  buying and selling firewood/charcoal and a general store. She lives in Toledo City, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2003 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 2,900. Laurita is borrowing PHP 10,000 to fund the operations of her business. This will be her 20th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 10,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Laurita aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF) is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed upon a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by joining the NWTF Kiva lending team at http://www.kiva.org

loans.use: To fund business operations

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel, age 32, earns his living as a motorbike taxi driver. He has been engaged in this business for five years and his business is well-organized. He gets up at 5 a.m. and works until 9 p.m. every day, transporting people to and from their workplaces. He and his wife have three children between the ages of three and seven years old. 

Emmanuel has requested a loan in the amount of 300,000 Rwf in order to buy essential materials for his motorbike. He will be repaying this loan over the course of eight months. His goal is to send all his siblings to school and to build a house for his family.

loans.use: to buy essential materials for his motorbike

loans.name: Venancia

texts.en:
Venancia L. is from the village of Kayok, Liloy, Zamboanga del Norte. She is 58 years old, married, and has two adult children. To make a living, Venancia owns and operates a clothing business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from providing general clothing services to local community members. Venancia has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month.

In 2011, Venancia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Venancia is requesting a loan of 7,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be Venancia's first loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita W. is from the village of Lagonglong, Misamis Oriental. She is 64 years old. She is separated from her spouse and has 1 school-aged child. To make a living, Rosita owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, selling canned goods, junk foods, shampoo, beverages & biscuits in the local community. Rosita has been engaged in her business for over 5 years and earns approximately 10000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rosita joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory & working capital. Rosita is requesting a new loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products, canned goods & junk foods. This will be the 6th loan taken out by Rosita from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products, canned goods & junk foods.

loans.name: Marilyn

texts.en:
This is Marilyn D., 38, resident of Victoria Reyes, Dasmariñas, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Adonis D., a contractual employee, and is the mother of four children, two of whom are in the elementary grades and the other two are not yet of school age. At this time, she is working hard to be able to send the rest of her children all the way through college. This is a dream for most Filipino parents like Marilyn, as she herself has been only through elementary school and believes that a college diploma is the best inheritance parents could leave to their children.

Marilyn is into the buying and selling of dried fish and smoked fish for quite some time now. She orders these items in large quantities from an individual who dries and smokes the fish.  She repacks the same into 5 PHP to 20 PHP packs for sale.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  Monthly, she earns an estimated net income of around $260.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 19,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy dried and smoked fish for her every day inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Marilyn dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. As a CCT community partner, she faithfully attends the group's weekly fellowship* meeting where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she receives.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for more dried and smoked fish for reselling.

loans.name: Moserrate Lourdes

texts.es:
En el sitio la pila del cantón Montecristi se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal  Para el Futuro De la Mujer. Este lugar es muy conocido en la provincia y en el país por su rica cultura tradicional, donde se puede encontrar una gran variedad de  artesanía que son elaboradas por sus habitantes siguiendo las costumbres tradicionales.

Aquí conocimos a Monserrate, tiene 31 años  de edad, está soltera y  vive en casa de sus padres.  Ella estudia Comercio Exterior en la  universidad Eloy Alfaro de Manta. Lleva en el Banco Comunal 5 años y le gustan los créditos ya que estos le  ayudan a financiar su negocio.

Ella además de sus estudios se dedica a la venta de ropa de todo tipo y productos de Yanbal (productos de belleza, cosméticos, perfumería y accesorios para damas). Trabaja tres o cuatro días a la semana, ella además de vender por su localidad también les vende a sus compañeras de clases,  deja sus productos a crédito y cobra cada semana. Sus productos los recibe en su casa y lo que es ropa la va a comprar cada fin de mes a Guayaquil ya que allá le salen más barato. Tiene diez años que se dedica a esta actividad y le va muy bien.

Este crédito es para comprar perfumes, cremas, cosméticos y ropa de todo tipo.
 
Su sueño es tener su propia empresa.
texts.en:
En el sitio la pila del cantón Montecristi se reúne cada quince días el Banco Comunal  Para el Futuro De la Mujer. Este lugar es muy conocido en la provincia y en el país por su rica cultura tradicional, donde se puede encontrar una gran variedad de  artesanía que son elaboradas por sus habitantes siguiendo las costumbres tradicionales.

The “Futuro de la Mujer” (Woman’s Future) communal bank meets every two weeks in La Pila, Montecristi Canton.  This place is very well known in the province and in the nation for its rich cultural tradition where one can find a great variety of crafts that are made by the residents following traditional customs.

We met Monserrate, 31, here.  She is single and living in her parents’ house.  She is studying International Commerce at Manta’s Eloy Alfaro University.  She’s been in the communal bank for 5 years and she likes the loans because they help finance her business.

Besides her studies she sells all types of clothes and Yanbal brand products (beauty products, cosmetics, perfumes and women’s accessories).  She works three or four days a week.  Besides selling among her community she also sells to her classmates.  She leaves her items on credit and collects weekly.  She receives her products at home and the clothes she buys in Guayaquil, which is where they are less expensive, at the end of each month.  She’s been in business for ten years and does very well.

This loan is to buy perfume, creams, cosmetics and clothes of all types.  Her dream is to own her own business.

loans.use: to buy perfume, creams, cosmetics and clothes.

loans.name: Belinda

texts.en:
Belinda is now 47 years old and married with four school-aged children. Belinda is a farmer working in the Philippines who earns PHP 8,000 a month. 

Belinda is asking for a loan of PHP 15,000 to purchase fertilizers such as manure and pay for services to increase crop yields. Belinda grows root crops and vegetables and has been doing this for almost 25 years.

In the future, Belinda  hopes to have a bigger farm lot where she can plant more vegetables.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and pay for services to increase crop yields

loans.name: Sebenzuphile Group

texts.en:
Fikile is 55 years old and widowed with four children, aged between 2 and 23. Three attend school. In the photo above she is standing in the middle of her group raising up her hand.

She sells live chickens, brooms, mats, baskets, bags and hats at the pay points in Hlabisa, South Africa. She has been in this business for three years. She also earns the government’s child support grant. 

She requested this loan through WDB and Kiva to buy live chickens, brooms, mats, baskets, bags and hats to resell.
 
In five years time she would like to extend her business and have at least two employees. She says that extra income from this loan will help her renovate her house and buy new furniture.
 
She appreciates WDB and Kiva for helping her with this loan and hopes that WDB and Kiva will come and visit her business and also give other women the opportunity of borrowing money as they did to her.

loans.use: To buy brooms, mats, baskets, bags and hats.

loans.name: Houmaiyetou

texts.fr: En 2007, Mme Houmaiyatou  a commencé par  vendre de façon ambulante des produits génériques après achat au Grand Marché de Lomé. Mère de 02 enfants, elle veut renforcer son activité en achetant plus de stock. Son conjoint est chauffeur.  En plus de produits génériques, elle vend des sachets plastiques.
texts.en: In 2007, Mrs. Houmaiyatou started selling generic products from place to place after stocking up at the main market in Lome.  Mother of 2 children, she would like to strengthen her business by buying more inventory.  Her husband is a driver.  In addition to generic products, she sells plastic bags.

loans.use: to buy generic products

loans.name: Indiana Del Carmen

texts.es: Indiana Del Carmen, se dedica a la actividad económica de mercadería en general. Hace más de 12 años que inicio este medio de vida, pues desde hace mucho tiempo en su familia le enseñaron a trabajar muy duro. Ella dio inicio porque tenía que sacar adelante a sus 3 hijos menores de edad, ya que además siempre le ha gustado el comercio. Indiana tiene que levantarse temprano para preparar su bolso y empezar a ofrecer cada uno de sus productos. Este crédito es para la compra de calzado, cosméticos, perfumes, shampoo, toallas y sabanas entre otros.
texts.en:
Indiana Del Carmen works in the economic field of selling general merchandise.  She started this way of life more than 12 years ago, as her family taught her to work hard long ago. She began because she had to raise her three young children, and in addition she has always liked to trade.  Indiana has to get up early to prepare her bag of merchandise and start offering each of her products. 

This loan is for the purchase of shoes, cosmetics, perfumes, shampoo, towels and sheets among other things.

loans.use: to buy shoes, cosmetics, perfumes, shampoo, towels and sheets among other things.

loans.name: Julio

texts.pt:
Nasceu no Distrito de Manjacaze, provincia de Gaza ao sul de Mocambique casado  e pai de 4 filhos de 3 a 11 anos de idade os mais velhos vaõ a Escola. Fez a 7ªclasse e parou devido a falta de condiçoes financeiras apos a perda do seu pai. Vive na casa propria com a sua familia e não sustenta mais ninguem.
Saiu de Gaza para Maputo  com a sua familia devido a guerra civil mais tarde fixou sua residencia. Tem um negocio proprio de venda de produtos alimentares e bebidas alcoolicas ha 4 anos e tem um   rendimento mensal de cerca de 6.000.00mt, o mesmo que aplica nas despesas de casa e poupa algum atravez de Xitique (sistema tradicional de poupança rotativa)
Nunca fez emprestimo noutros bancos, conheceu Hluvuku atravez de um amigo que tambem é cliente da instituição. Este é o seu primeiro emprestimo na Hluvuku no valor de 20.000.00mt, com qual pretende comprar produtos (cerveja, vinho, refrescos, feijaõ e outros ) para aumentar a quantidade da sua mercadoria e responder a demanda.
Esta confiante que vai pagar de acordo com o calendario estabelecido, futuramente pretende ampliar o seu negocio e comprar um carro para ajudar no escoamento do produto e para tal tenciona solicitar mais emprestimos a Hluvuku.
texts.en:
Julio was born in the district of Manjacaze, in the Gaza province of southern Mozambique.  He is married and has 4 children ages 3 to 11.  The eldest attend school.  He completed school through the seventh grade but dropped out due to financial circumstances after the death of his father. He lives in his own home with his family and does not support anyone else.  

He left Gaza for Maputo with his family due to the civil war and later established residence there.  He has had his own business selling groceries and alcoholic beverages for four years and he earns around 6.000.00mt per month.  He uses this money to cover his household expenses and he saves some through Xitique, a traditional method of community savings. 

Julio has never had a loan in other banks.  He learned about Hluvuku through a friend who is also a client.  This is his first loan with Hluvuku, in the amount of 20.000.00mt, which he will use to purchase products (beer, wine, soft drinks, beans, etc.) to increase his stock and respond to customer demand.  

He is confident that he will make his payments on time.  In the future he would like to expand his business and purchase a car to help transport products. He plans to request further loans from Hluvuku for that purpose.

loans.use: topurchase products for sale (beer, wine, softdrinks, beans, etc.)

loans.name: Livingstone

texts.en:
Livingstone is 32 years old, married, and they have two children aged six and two years old. He operates a shoe sales business at a local market in Kakamega. He has been in this business for three years now. He says the business is profitable and the only major challenge he has are financial constraints.

Livingstone plans to use this loan to purchase shoes to expand his business. In the future, he hopes to grow his business to the wholesale level. He also has hopes of buying a plot of land on which he will put up rental houses. He describes himself as a visionary man.

loans.use: to purchase shoes to expand his business.

loans.name: Djèkafo  4 Group

texts.fr:
Composé de huit membres, Les membres du groupe Djèkafo 4 de Sirakorobougou sont mariées dans des grandes familles traditionnelles, ont en moyenne 39 ans, 5 enfants et habitent le village de Sirakorobougou dans la commune rurale de Tissala dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali).
Dans le but d’augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1er cycle de prêt de campagne. Les membres du groupe vont cultiver l’arachide, le mil et le niébé.
Madame Kadia (Assise au milieu) compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter, un sac d’urée et recruter la main d’œuvre pour se faire aider dans les travaux de labour et de sarclage de ses champs. Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricoles à la foire de Tissala. Le labour et le sarclage sont  l’œuvre des hommes du village. Elle compte récolter sur une superficie de 2 hectares: 3 sacs de mil, 20 sacs d’arachide, 2 sacs de niébé et des fanes. Une partie de sa production est utilisée en famille pour aider son mari à la prise en charge de la consommation familiale. Le reste est vendu pour subvenir aux besoins du foyer. Madame Kadia  a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans son foyer.
texts.en:
The Djèkafo 4 group of Sirakorobougou comprises eight members who are married and live in traditional extended households. They are on average 39 years old with 5 children and live in the town of Sirakorobougou, in the rural district of Tissala in the Ségou region (4th administrative region of Mali).
With the goal of increasing their farming area, they turned to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their first farming loan cycle. The group members are going to grow groundnuts, millet, and black-eyed peas.
Ms. Kadia (sitting in the middle of the photo) intends to use her loan to buy 1 bag of urea and to recruit manual labour to help her with physical tasks and hoeing. She gets her supplies of agricultural inputs at the Tissala market fair. Labour and hoeing are done by the men in the town. From her 2 hectares of land, she intends to harvest 3 sacks of millet, 20 sacks of groundnuts, 2 sacks of black-eyed peas, and greens. A portion of her harvest is used within the family to help her husband take care of food requirements. The rest is sold to meet the needs of the household. Ms. Kadia's goal is to ensure self-sufficiency in food for her household.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pay for manual labour for hoeing.

loans.name: Alejandrina Laura

texts.es:
La Señora. Alejandrina es socia del banco comunal Loma de la Cruz, vive en la ciudad de Cuenca, esta ciudad es la tercera ciudad más importante del país, fue nombrada patrimonio cultural de la humanidad en diciembre de 1999, su gente mantiene su cultura, tradiciones y su gastronomía es muy variada.

Doña Alejandrina tiene 32 años, es casada y fruto de su unión conyugal ha concebido 3 hijos de 14, 12 y 11 años de edad que estudian en el colegio. Su esposo labora como agente vendedor, no tiene casa propia por lo que viven arrendando.

La Señora. Alejandrina se dedica a la venta de ropa por catalogo y cosméticos, lleva 6 años con este negocio y labora de lunes a viernes medio día ya que el resto de su tiempo se dedica a sus hijos.
 
En el banco comunal se encuentra hace 8 años y su nuevo crédito lo va a invertir en la compra de cosméticos y ropa para seguir creciendo en su negocio.

Su sueño es tener una casa propia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Alejandrina is a member of the Loma de la Cruz communal bank. She lives in the city of Cuenca. This is the third most important city in the country. It was named a World Heritage Site in December 1999. Its people maintain their culture and traditions, and their gastronomy is very varied.

Mrs. Alejandrina is 32. She is married and has 3 children from this relationship. They are 14, 12, and 11, and are all in school. Her husband works as a sales agent. They do not have their own home, as they rent.

Mrs. Alejandrina sells cosmetics, and clothing through a catalogue. She has had this business for 6 years and works half days Monday to Friday, since she spends the rest of the time with her children.

She has been a member of the communal bank for 8 years and she will invest her new loan in the purchase of cosmetics and clothing in order for her business to continue growing.

Her dream is to have her own home.

loans.use: to purchase cosmetics and clothing.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria is a 45-year-old lady who is married to Mikael, a 52-year-old laborer. They have three children: Dominggus, 22, Flavianus, 19 and Gresensiana, 12, who is studying in the sixth grade of elementary school. 
In order to support her husband in meeting their family’s needs, Maria runs a kiosk business. This business has been operating for years. Her husband supported her with capital to set up the business by purchasing stock such as noodles, sugar, coffee, various snacks, cigarettes, detergent, soap, etc. She likes to run this business to support her husband in generating more income for her family.
Maria is wanting to add more stock of basic household items in her kiosk such as rice, vegetables, cooking oil, betel nuts, betel vine, etc. She needs more capital to do so. Therefore, she is requesting a loan of 10,000,000 IDR from Kiva partner, TLM. She hopes TLM is willing to assist her in improving her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock such as rice, vegetables, cooking oil, betel nuts, betel vine, etc.

loans.name: Walter Carlos

texts.es:
Walter de 29 años de edad, es soltero, vive en la casa de sus padres, cuenta con servicio sólo de luz, ubicado en el distrito de Paijan que pertenece al departamento de La Libertad.  Estas zonas se dedican a la agricultura y ganadería.

La actividad que desarrolla Walter es brindar el servicio de transporte público, ya que cuenta con su propia mototaxi, la cual lo trabaja mañana y tarde movilizando personas que viven en Paijan, cuenta con su propia clientela y con los ingresos que obtenga puede cubrir sus gastos de su casa.

Ha solicita un préstamo a Edpyme Alternativa de 1200 nuevos soles para brindarle mantenimiento y cambio de repuestos de su mototaxi.  Walter es una persona muy conocida en el lugar donde vive porque siempre se preocupa por el bienestar de los suyos, con el fin que en un futuro pueda tener una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Walter is 29 years old, single, and lives at home with his parents. The only service he receives is electricity. Walter resides in the District of Paijan, which is part of the Department of La Libertad. This area is known for agriculture and livestock breeding.

Walter’s business involves providing public transportation services. He has his own motorcycle taxi that he drives in the morning and afternoons in order to transport people who live in Paijan. Walter has his own customer base and the income he generates helps to cover his household expenses.

He is requesting a loan from Edpyme Alternativa in the amount of 1200 PEN so that he can maintain his motorcycle taxi and replace the parts. Walter is a person who is well-known in the area where he lives because he is concerned about the welfare of his family. His goal for the future is to have a better quality of life.

loans.use: to maintain his motorcycle taxi and replace the parts.

loans.name: Herbert

texts.en:
Herbert is 35 years old and lives in the town of Mukono in the Mukono region of Uganda. He is married and has three children. Two of the children are currently in school. For the past five years, Herbert has been working hard to manage his small shop in which he sells fresh produce. 

To help expand his business, Herbert has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to buy larger volumes of produce to sell in his shop and will help Herbert to generate greater profits and allow him to hire more employees. Herbert hopes that in the future, he will be able to have a very big business. 

Herbert is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Herbert who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for micro loans.

loans.use: to buy larger volumes of produce to sell in his shop,

loans.name: Kassafor Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe de solidarité est créé le 08 mai 2001. Il  est  constitué de 14 femmes qui habitent le même quartier. Leur activité principale est le commerce.

Madame Seynabou qui est à la droite de la photo levant la main est responsable de groupe. Elle est âgée de 53 ans. Elle est mariée et mère de huit enfants. 

Elle s’active dans la vente de balais, netetou, sucre. Elle a une bonne expérience dans ce domaine d’activité, qu'elle a pratiqué depuis plus de 20 ans.
Ce prêt lui permettra de renforcer son capital et de mieux développer  ses activités.
Les profits lui permettront d’améliorer les conditions de vie de la famille (santé, nourriture, habillement etc.…) et d’augmenter ses épargnes.
texts.en:
This cooperative group was created on May 8, 2001, and is made up of 14 women who live in the same neighborhood.  Their main business is sales.

Mrs. Seynabou, with hand raised at the right of the photo, is the group leader.  She is 53 years old, married, and the mother of eight children.

She sells brooms, nététou (a local spicy seasoning), and sugar.  She has significant experience in this business, which she has been in for more than 20 years.

This loan will allow her to strengthen her capital and better develop her business.  The profits will help her improve her family's living conditions (health, food, clothing, etc.) and increase her savings.

loans.use: to buy brooms, spices, and sugar.

loans.name: Saidmurod

texts.ru: Саидмурод житель района Яван. Ему 57 лет. Он женат. У него шестеро детей. Он имеет среднее образование. Зарабатывает путем разведения мелко – рогатого скота. Кредит берет для закупа овцы.
texts.en: Saidmurod lives in the Yavan district.  He is 57 years old, married and has six children.  He has a secondary education.  Saidmurod earns a living by breeding small livestock.  He is requesting this loan for the purchase of sheep.

loans.use: to buy sheep

loans.name: Conchita

texts.en:
Conchita is married and has 5 children. she is 43 years old and lives in the Philippines.

Conchita is a farmer and grows rice to earn a living. She has been farming for 20 years. She has requested a loan of 11,000 to purchase fertilizer for rice. 
Conchita has been a member of PMPC for 4 years. In the future, she hopes to see her children finish college.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for rice.

loans.name: Editha

texts.en:
Editha is a married woman. She has two adult children. She’s a very hardworking woman who very much wants to get ahead and improve herself more every day. She sells cosmetics and clothes. She chose this work because she enjoys selling. She’s been working for about a year and earns P 260 per week. She is requesting a loan of P 7,000 to purchase dress, lotion, bags and accessories to have more additional income.

Editha’s main dream is to have a spa at home and to become a professional. She’s very grateful for the loan granted because she’ll be able to reach her goals with it.

loans.use: to buy dresses, lotion, bags and accessories for sale

loans.name: José William

texts.es: José William de 33 años  de edad, habita en casa familiar junto con su grupo familiar el cual está conformado por su compañera de vida y sus dos hijas las cuales se encuentran cursando sus primeros años de estudio.  José se dedica a la venta de gas propano. Tiene muchos años de dedicarse a esta actividad y gracias a Dios y a su esfuerzo los resultados han sido satisfactorios. Para él lo más importante es su familia y es por ella que lucha día a día para poder darles lo que se merecen. Además no pierde las esperanzas de ver a sus hijas convertidas en grandes profesionales. José se caracteriza por ser luchador, responsable y dedicado en su trabajo. Ha estado pensando mucho la posibilidad de mejorar su negocio es decir invertir más con el fin de abarcar una mayor demanda. Esto lo ha llevado a solicitar este crédito a INTEGRAL para invertir en su pequeño negocio en la compra de gas propano al por mayor ya que se acerca la temporada navideña y tiene la confianza de que en esta época las ventas mejoraran por lo que quiere estar preparado.  No pierde la esperanza que de esta manera logrará mejora su calidad de vida y la de su familia.
texts.en:
José William, age 33, lives in his family home with his partner and their two daughters, who are in their first years of primary school. José selss propane gas. He has been doing this for many years - and thanks to God, as well as the effort he has put in, business has been very satisfactory. 

The most important thing in José's life is his family, and it is for them that he strives day by day, to give them everything they deserve. He has a hope that he might see his daughters grow up to be educated professional people. José describes himself as being determined, responsible, and dedicated to his work. He has been thinking that he could improve his business by investing more with the aim of expanding into a bigger market. This decision has brought him to seek a loan with INTEGRAL to invest in his small business buy buying more propane in wholesale quantities. Christmas time is coming and he is confident that sales will increase around this time, so he wants to be well prepared. He hopes that by expanding in this way he will succeed in improving his family's quality of life.

loans.use: To buy propane gas at wholesale

loans.name: Elizabeth Marlene

texts.es:
Elizabeth  vive y trabaja en famous Nazca, or Nasca, Perú. The city is well known for the legendary Nazca Lines- a series of ancient, immense and inexplicable geoglyphs etched into the desert surrounding the city, generally attributed to the Nazca culture, which inhabited in the region from 300-800 AD. As such, the city attracts a considerable amount of tourism. But Nazca is also known for its hardworking people, who have preserved despite frequent earthquakes, tsunamis, and a high level of poverty in the region.
Elizabeth es una mujer separada, tiene un  hijo de 15 años el cual esta cursando el nivel secundario, ella se dedica a la venta de gaseosas y recargas virtuales movistar, empezó con un pequeño capital que su tío le otorgo.  Elizabeth es una  mujer trabajadora y muy empeñosa con muchas ganas de sacar a delante  a su hijo, empezó en el negocio hace 5 años y gana un promedio de S/. 200.00 soles semanales.
Con el crédito que le otorgará Kiva de S/. 1000.00 soles lo invertirá para la compra de tarjetas virtuales ( claro y movistar),  para que de esta manera pueda tener mas ingresos para poderle dar una mejor calidad de vida a su hijo, uno de sus sueños es tener su propia casa y que su hijo llegue  a ser un gran profesional, su asesor cree que es un buen cliente y que va a pagar puntualmente sus cuotas.
texts.en:
Elizabeth lives and works in the famous Nazca, or Nasca, Perú. The city is well known for the legendary Nazca Lines- a series of ancient, immense and inexplicable geoglyphs etched into the desert surrounding the city, generally attributed to the Nazca culture, which inhabited the region from 300-800 AD. As such, the city attracts a considerable amount of tourism. However, Nazca is also known for its hardworking people, who have persevered despite frequent earthquakes, tsunamis, and a high level of poverty in the region.

Elizabeth is separated and has a 15-year-old son who is in secondary school. She makes a living selling soft drinks and virtual Movistar [a local cellular service company] cell phone credits. She started with a small amount of capital that her uncle gave her. Elizabeth is a hardworking and diligent woman with a great desire to help her son get ahead. She started the business five years ago and makes an average of 200 PEN a week.

With the 1,000 PEN loan from Kiva she will invest in the purchase of virtual cell phone credits (Claro and Movistar [local cellular service companies]). In this way she will have more income to be able to give her son a better quality of life. One of her dreams is to have her own house and that her son will become a great professional. Her loan advisor believes that she is a good client and that she will make her repayments on time.

loans.use: to purchase virtual cell phone credits (Movistar and Claro).

loans.name: Kwame Nkuruma Group

texts.en:
Delfina, who is in her late 30s, is married with two children who are still going to school.  She has been running two businesses, poultry and charcoal sales, for three years now.  She works from 8.00am to 6.00 pm daily and is able to make a good monthly profit.

This will be her 3rd loan from Tujijenge Tanzania.  She used the previous loans to buy chicken feeds, started selling charcoal and household expenses. She has paid back all her loans successfully. She wants a loan to buy more chicks and more sacks of charcoal .  Her dream is to one day be able to expand her businesses.

She will share this loan with her loan group "Kwame Nkuruma" which has a total of 18 members who will hold each other accountant able for paying back their loans.

loans.use: to buy more chicks and more sacks of charcoal.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose, 54, lives in Silang, Cavite City, Philippines with her husband and three children. She earns a living by running a small convenience store where she sells groceries, toiletries and beverages to people who live in her area. She earns about PHP 800 a day and is applying for a loan for PHP 23,000 to buy more items to sell to her customers. Her goal is to expand her business and provide her children with a good future. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and study religion. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 partners.

loans.use: to buy more items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es:
A sus 59 años,  Julia se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en una pequeña bodega que posee, en este momento se encuentra viviendo con una de sus 7 hijos, todos ya son mayores de edad y cada uno es independiente, ella vive en la ciudad de Mala, ciudad ubicada aproximadamente a 1 hora de media de la capital del Perú, Lima.

La señora Julia es una mujer que a pesar de edad quiere continuar saliendo adelante y poder brindarse los ingresos necesarios que le permitan tener una mejor calidad de vida. Este negocio se inició gracias al dinero que percibía como pensión, decidió incursionar en este tipo de negocio e invertir el dinero que le ingresa mensualmente. Para poder seguir creciendo en su pequeña empresa, ella trabaja todos los días durante dos turnos uno desde las 7 a.m. hasta las 12 p.m. y en la tarde desde las 2 p.m. hasta las 9 p.m., este horario le permite tener un ingreso de S/.30 diarios.

Gracias a los prestatarios Kiva ella podrá comprar mucha más mercadería (Abarrotes en general) y variar sus productos para satisfacer las necesidades y gustos de sus clientes. Su sueño es poder ampliar su negocio, comprando (mostradores, una congeladora, entre otros), conversando con sus clientes ella también se ha podido dar cuenta que sería buena idea empezar a vender ropa, pero estas metas serán logradas sólo si su esfuerzo y dedicación se incrementan diariamente.
texts.en: At 59 years old, Julia sells groceries in a small bodega that she owns. At the moment, she is living with one of her seven children, who are all grown-up and independent. She lives in the city of Mala, which is located approximately one hour, on average, from Lima, the capital city of Peru. Ms. Julia is a woman who, despite her age, wants to continue improving so that she will be able to bring in the necessary income to have a better quality of life. She started her business thanks to the money she receives as a pension. She decided to venture into this type of business and invest the money that she receives each month. In order to keep growing her small business, she works every day in shifts -- one from 7:00 a.m. to 12:00 p.m. and the other in the afternoon from 2:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. This schedule allows her to earn about 30 nuevos soles a day. Thanks to Kiva lenders, she will be able to buy much more merchandise (groceries in general) and diversify her products to satisfy the needs and preferences of her customers. Her dream is to be able to expand her business (to buy counters and a freezer, among other things). From talking to her customers, she has also realized that it would be a good idea to start selling clothing. She will only achieve these goals if her effort and dedication keep growing each day.

loans.use: to buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Florentina

texts.en:
Arnel is 18 years old and is the third of three children in the family. His mother Florentina has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for many years. She supports the family through her welding shop business in the Philippines.

Arnel is studying for a Bachelor of Science in Marine Transportation and is currently in the third year level of this four-year course.

Florentina is borrowing PHP 14,500 to pay for tuition fees for the first semester for her son Arnel.

When Arnel graduates, he plans to be gainfully employed and help his family.

loans.use: to pay for her son's tuition fees.

loans.name: Twungurane Sub Group B

texts.en:
Geturde is a group leader aged 32 years. She is married with two children aged 5 and 10 years. They both go to school.

The group is called Twungurane Sub Group B; "Twungurane" means “Help” in English. They sell different products and they wish to expand their businesses for positive change and a better future.

She sells foodstuffs and has been running her business for six years. With the loan, she would like to buy more vegetables to sell. The profits from the business will be used to improve her welfare and to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: to buy more vegetables to sell.

loans.name: Baraka Women Group(Mtungi Moja)

texts.en:
The lady raising her hand in the photo is Josphine. She is thirty three years old, married and blessed with three children. She is a member of Baraka women group (Mtungi Moja) which joined Hand in Hand Eastern Africa in the year 2014 and has benefited from enterprise development and financial management training.
She does dairy and maize farming. She is borrowing from Kiva to purchase fertilizer and dairy feeds that will consequently increase her produce and income. This will assist her cater for the family needs such as food, medicine and in paying school fees for her children. 
She is grateful to Kiva and their lenders and promises to pay promptly.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer and dairy feeds hence increase in produce and income to cater for food and medicine for her family and pay school fees for her children.

loans.name: Eorn

texts.en:
T. Eorn and his family used to live in Phnom Penh city, near to a pagoda. They moved 12 days ago because the Cambodian government granted them a piece of land in this new village, around 25 kilometers away from the center of the city.

T. Eorn is married and lives with his wife and 5 children. His two eldest daughters are already working in a factory, making $45 per month, while two of his children are still going to school and two stay with her wife at home. He is employed by the government and earns $120 monthly.

T. Earn requested $500 to build a house for his family to live properly. He stressed their need to have toilets installed in her house. The village is not yet connected to the power and the water grids but she expect this to be done soon. When her loan will be disbursed, T. Eorn will purchase raw materials and hire two people for three weeks, until the works are completed.

“This new house is a real chance for the 7 of us”, she said, “because living outside the city is good for our health and safer for our children”.

loans.use: Building a new house for his family

loans.name: Rosidah

texts.en:
R. is 32 years old, and is married with two children, both girls aged 15 and 10. The eldest is attending senior high school, while the younger one is in elementary school. Her husband, Salim, does not have a fixed job, so he does odd jobs, carrying goods and off-loading trucks when he can.

R. buys waste material like plastic cups, plastic bottles, cardboard and paper from her neighbors and other houses in the village. Her husband uses a cart to collect scrap metal and other waste material. Households do not just give away waste material, because there is demand and therefore economic value in recycling. So the more working capital they have, the more scrap they can collect and recycle. Their own working capital is limited, at around $250. Having heard from her friends about MBK, R. has now applied to MBK to add to her working capital. Since this is the first time, R. can only borrow a maximum of $75 from MBK.

The recycling business consists of the following chain. R. and her husband are the first link in this chair, buying waste and scrap materials from households, sorting and cleaning them, before selling them to an intermediate dealer. This dealer comes around in a small truck, collects the sorted-out material and takes it to the warehouse dealer. There, the different materials are weighed in front of R.’s husband, who then gets paid by the intermediate dealer. The warehouse dealer in turn sends the waste material to various processing factories, which turn produce clean and reusable recycled paper, cardboard and plastic recycled raw materials. Waste recycling undertaken by R. and her husband thus helps clean the environment by reusing waste material which otherwise would go to the landfills.

loans.use: Purchase waste material

loans.name: Aniva

texts.en: Aniva is fifty-four years of age and has six children.  Aniva believs that her small business really helps her raise her family’s standard of living.  She is also very confident of her abilities to run the business, especially since she has support from her family and friends, and they believe in her enterprise.  She started off with only one product – selling baked fish in her local village; but with previous SPBD loans, she explored adding a second product, baked chicken.  Since she started, she feels that her customer base has grown a lot and she feels there is more growth possible if she is able to expand her supply and product line.  Aniva admits to working very hard to make this business a success and is proud of her efforts.  She is confident that she is able to provide the best quality goods with the lowest prices in the village.  Aniva will use the loan funds to purchase larger supplies of fish and chicken as well as some basic baking supplies.

loans.use: Purchase ingredients and baking supplies

texts.en: Mrs. H. is 49 years old, and her husband is 50. They have three children, ages 19 to 26 who all have left the house. They live in Nghe An, a rural province in the upper center of Vietnam. Mrs. H. raises pigs and washes dishes for the next door restaurant; her husband fixes bicycles. She wants to buy more breeding pigs to increase her income. A breeding pig will give birth to piglets after three months and can do that twice a year. Mrs. H. earns $25.00 per month with dishwashing and the pig raising gives her an extra $50.00 per month.

loans.use: to buy more breeding pigs

loans.name: Amadu Bamkolo

texts.en: Amadu Bamkolo K. sells fuel and lubricant in the village of Fadugu in Sierra Leone.  He is forty-eight years old, married with three teenage children.  With his previous loan, Amadu increased his stock and used the profit to diversify his business.  He purchased a goat and sheep and he plans to establish animal husbandry that will include cows.  He is requesting a loan of $175 to increase his fuel business and to begin his dream.

loans.use: Increase fuel business for future diversification of the business.

loans.name: Hairiniso

texts.ru:
Hairiniso, 55, has been in business for a few years. She is married and has 4 children. Her husband works for the state. Hairiniso’s older son and daughter help her in business. Hairiniso buys her inventory from a wholesaler in Istaravshan. Hairiniso increased the sales volume a few times over the 3 years that she has been a MicroInvest client. She plans to invest this loan into ongoing expansion of her business.

Translated from Russian by Aleksandr Zhuk, Kiva Volunteer.

Хайринисо 55 лет, но, несмотря на свой возраст, она уже несколько лет занимается бизнесом. Хайринисо замужем и у нее 4 детей. Муж тоже работает на государственной службе. В бизнесе ей помогают старшие сын и дочь. За товаром она ездит на оптовый рынок г. Истаравшан. Клиентом Микроинвест является 3 года. за этот период обороты ее бизнеса возросли в несколько раз. Хайринисо планирует получить новый займ на дальнейшее расширение своего бизнеса.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Omua

texts.en: Mrs. Omua O. is a fashion designer by profession. She is 32 years old, married with 2 children, and she lives in Benin City, Edo State, Nigeria. She has been in this business since 2002. She requests a loan of $475 to enable her buy more cloth and tailoring material to make clothes for sale.

loans.use: To buy more cloth and tailoring material

loans.name: Sarah's Group

texts.en:
Sarah S. wants to set up her own bakery. She is requesting a loan to purchase baking supplies. In addition, she also wants to buy a fridge with the loan.

Background on BRAC and BRAC Uganda

BRAC (Building Resources Across Communities) is a development organization that began operations in Bangladesh as a small-scale relief and rehabilitation project in 1972 to help the country overcome the devastation and trauma of the liberation war and focused on resettling refugees returning from India. Today, BRAC has emerged as an independent, virtually self-financed paradigm in sustainable human development. It is one of the largest Southern development organizations employing over 100,000 people, 61% of which are women, and working with the twin objectives of poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor. Diagnosing poverty in human terms and recognizing its multifaceted nature, BRAC approaches poverty alleviation with a holistic approach.

The successes of BRAC in the international development arena have stimulated a series of discussions, both with African delegations, who have visited BRAC programs, and with donors who work in Asia and Africa. Both the African countries and the donors have encouraged BRAC to join the development campaign in Africa to achieve the Millennium Development Goals (MDGs) and more recently to join the campaign of “ending poverty”, which is an area where Africa represents the greatest global challenge.

In Uganda, BRAC registered as a Non Government Organization (NGO) in January 2006 to undertake programs in Education, Health, Water & Sanitation, Agriculture & Livestock and Microfinance. The Microfinance and Education are the pioneer programs launched in Uganda and, as of July 2007, had served 21,273 borrowers and enrolled 1,155 adolescents in its education program.

loans.use: To set up a bakery

loans.name: Anong

texts.en: Anong, 47, is the mother of a child aged 22; her husband had passed away a long time ago. To provide for her family's needs, she has been selling vegetables door-to-door around the villages and earns $10 a day. She is a member of MBK and asks for a loan of $75 to buy goods to sell. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Buy more goods

loans.name: Ligia

texts.es:
Señora Ligia is a member of the communal bank Las Perlas de Pucallpa, located on Avenue Sáenz Peña in the district of Calleria in Ucayali. Ligia is 51 years old and a mother of three daughters. With her first loan of 300 Soles she decided to invest in clothing sales.

Presently she continues with the clothing business, buts she also sells OmniLife products. Since her children are already independent and she is separated, she is dedicated to the business for which she must go out a lot to offer products and gain more earnings.

With the loan of 1000 Soles, which she will pay back in five months, she will invest in purchasing clothes and also buying products of OmniLife.

Ligia is a mother who found out how to help her daughters move ahead in life, and although in difficult moments she had to fight, she never surrendered. Now her daughters support her and she feels peaceful and good about her self.

Translated from Spanish by Jay Osborne, Kiva volunteer

La señora Ligia pertenece al banco comunal Las Perlas de Pucallpa, ubicado en la Av. Sáenz Peña N° 469, distrito de Calleria, departamento de Ucayali. Ligia tiene 51 años y es madre de 3 hijas. Con su primer préstamo de S/ 300 decidió invertir en la venta de ropas.

En la actualidad continúa con el negocio de ropa, pero también vende productos omnilife. Como sus hijos ya son independientes y ella es separada se dedica a los negocios para lo cual tiene que salir mucho para ofrecer y tener más ganancias.

Con el préstamo de S/ 1,000 soles, el cual pagará en 5 meses, invertirá en la compra de ropa y también invertirá en la compra de productos omnilife.

Ligia es una madre que supo sacar adelante a sus hijas y aún en los momentos más difíciles que tuvo que atravesar nunca sé rindió y ahora sus hijas la apoyan y se siente más tranquila y bien consigo misma.

loans.use: Buy clothing

loans.name: Juliet Nakamatte’S Group

texts.en:
Juliet, age 30, is the leader of this five-person group. This is the group’s first loan with MCDT. Juliet is married with four children. All of her children are in school, except for her youngest. Her husband sells used refrigerators.

Juliet has a business selling poultry and pigs. She plans to use the loan to buy more chickens and increase her feed stock. If things go well, she would like to expand her living space and increase the size of her business. She also hopes that the profits from her business will be enough to pay school fees for her children.

loans.use: To buy chickens and feed

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora is 41 years old, and she is the mother of five children, all of whom are in school. She has been selling grocery products for two years, and she has recently added certain products such as fresh pineapples, plantains, and cocoyams to her business's inventory. While she sells her foodstuffs in the local city where she is able to generate considerable sales, she has to buy her grocery products from Accra and the foodstuffs from another nearby village.

As such, Dora is seeking a loan to buy more bags of pineapple, sacks of plantains, and cocoyams, as well as other groceries such as canned tomatoes, canned fish, soap, and evaporated milk.

She is a member of the group called “Eye Yehowa” (meaning, "it is God"). Group members exert positive peer pressure on each other as social collateral to encourage the group members to promptly repay their respective loans.

loans.use: To expand her inventory by purchasing additional food and grocery products (e.g., pineapple, cocoyams, and plantains).

loans.name: Mabira Development Group

texts.en:
Muwanga N. is the chairperson of Mabira Development Group, a group that has been together for 10 years. She has a retail shop business selling soda, juice and mineral water in Najjembe, located in the middle of Mabira forest on the Kampala - Jinja road. It is also a common place for selling roasted meat, chicken, yellow bananas and gonja to passengers in moving vehicles. She employs a total of five boys and girls to do the running around with cold water and juice to passengers in the stopping vehicles. The profits they make are shared with her as their daily wage; meaning the more they sell, the more they earn. Muwanga is a married woman with eight children of whom four are still in school. She takes care of one of her sick sister’s children, paying for school fees in a boarding section, plus one grandchild not yet in school.

Muwanga needs a loan to buy more soda, mineral water and juice for her shop. Her dream is to own a much bigger shop with more soda, mineral water and juice plus other goods like sugar, tea leaves and other foodstuffs to accompany her drinks.

Muwanga will share this loan with the members of her group. The group is really thankful to Kiva for giving them this opportunity.

loans.use: To buy more soda, mineral water and juice for her shop.

loans.name: Martha Isabel

texts.es:
Martha Isabel C. works very hard running a tailor's shop from her home in the county of La Paz Centro in the city of Leon. She has been doing this for 20 long years and throughout this time she has managed to gather a lot of experience in her field.

She is a single mother with a young son that she must support. Her multiple efforts are all so that she can feed him and pay for his education. Now she is asking for a loan so that she can buy equipment for her work such as needles, thread, material and more. This is why she is looking for financing from Ceprodel; so that she can get the necessary credit and therefore continue with her business.

Translated from Spanish by Liz Harvey, Kiva Volunteer

En el municipio de La Paz Centro de la ciudad de León, la señora Martha Isabel C. se dedica a trabajar en el negocio de sastrería el cual atiende muy esforzadamente en su casa de habitación. SE dedica a este negocio desde hace 20 largos años y a través de este tiempo ha logrado alcanzar una basta experiencia en su ramo.

Es madre soltera y con un pequeño hijo con el deber de mantener. Sus múltiples esfuerzos los realiza para brindarle el alimento a su pequeño y así poder continuar con sus estudios. Hoy en día solicita un crédito para la compra de sus materiales de trabajo como lo es hilos, agujas, telas y mas. Por esto busca el financiamiento en Ceprodel para obtener el crédito necesario y de esta manera continuar en su negocio.

loans.use: To buy materials to work with/Compra de materiales para trabajo

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
Nancy is a hard-working woman who spends her time selling candy and drinks in a small store that she built years ago. This business has helped her cover living expenses for her four children. Nancy puts a lot into her store, because she knows that if she works hard she can turn it into a prosperous business. For this reason she hopes to start improving it by supplying new merchandise and a diverse set of products that are difficult to find in the region but can satisfy her clients' needs. Nancy believes that if she can supply these products, her business will attract more visits from her neighbors. Nancy needs 1500 soles to complete the quality improvements, and she promises to be punctual and responsible in her repayments.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Bishop, Kiva Volunteer.

Nancy es una mujer emprendedora que trabaja en la venta de dulces y de bebidas en la pequeña tienda que instaló hace un par de años. Dicho negocio le ayuda a solventar los gastos de sus cuatro hijos.Ella está muy entregada a su tienda, porque sabe que si se esfuerza más podrá hacer de él un negocio muy prospero, por ello, desea empezar a mejorarlo desde ya, surtirlo con nueva mercadería y diversos productos que sean difíciles de encontrar en la zona para poder satisfacer la necesidad de sus clientes, así propiciar la mayor concurrencia de sus vecinos a su bodega.La suma que requiere para ello es de 1500 soles, que espera que usted, pueda brindarle en calidad de préstamo y con la promesa de ser puntual y responsable en sus pagos.

loans.use: Buy new, unique merchandise for her store

loans.name: Aziz

texts.en:
C. Aziz is a widower. He is a businessman of 27 who deals in a variety of merchandise: mirrors, needles, thread, soap, shampoo, toothbrushes and other small items. He sells his merchandise on both a retail and a wholesale basis. His business is located in the local market.

His sister who is pictured in the photo helps Aziz with the business. Aziz is looking after two dependant children: a girl aged 7 and a boy of 5. He has been able to meet the needs of the children using the income from his business but unfortunately this leaves him with almost no savings available as capital for investment.

Aziz is requesting a loan of 2000 Somoni (600 USD) to expand his business. When this is achieved, he believes he will be able to save money to buy a plot of land where he can construct a house. This loan will be repaid in 3 months. Aziz thanks all for their support and promises to manage the loan without any violations.

loans.use: Purchasing goods in order to enlarge his inventory

loans.name: Debora

texts.en:
Mambo from Tanzania! This is forty-six year old Debora M. from Mwanza. She is married with seven children, between the ages of eight and thirty-five. Debora has been running a grocery business since 2005. Her business is selling soda, biscuits, tea leaves, sugar, and flour. She works at the business for sixteen hours per day, six days per week. Debora currently earns about US$ 200 from her business. She is requesting a loan of US$ 450 in order to buy maize flour, soda, rice, and wheat flour. In the future, she plans to increase the quantity and range of of her stock. Debora thanks you for your support!

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. The organization is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through the provision of a leasing and leaseback microfinance facility. Customs and traditions in Tanzania make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed non-creditworthy by financial institutions. This leads to poor financial support and poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes. One of the primary advantages of micro leasing is that it allows clients to use the equipment as collateral for future loans with SELFINA, thus enabling them to borrow larger sums in the future.

loans.use: To buy maize flour, soda, rice, and wheat flour

loans.name: Marivel

texts.es:
La señora Marivel, socia del Banco Comunal “Las Victorias”, vive en el departamento de San Martín, provincia de Mariscal Cáceres, distrito de Juanjui. Se dedica a la reparación y venta repuestos para artefactos, sobre todo brinda mantenimiento de computadoras. El negocio está ubicado en el  Jr. La Merced Nº 931,  lugar donde a diario acuden sus clientes que cada día aumentan por la calidad de su trabajo y los repuestos que oferta.

Con este crédito de S/.1,500, el cual será cancelado en en 6 meses, comprará repuestos y accesorios diversos, los cuales necesita en la realización de sus trabajos, eso da confianza y seguridad a sus servicio y sobre todo la satisfacción de sus clientes, que es lo más importante para ella.   

La señora Marivel tiene 35 años de edad, vive con su esposo y con sus 02 hijos, quienes son su motor para seguir trabajando y para darles un futuro mejor. Es una mujer muy optimista que anhela más adelante ampliar y arreglar su local.
texts.en:
Marivel, a member of the Las Victorias community bank, lives in Juanjuí, in the Mariscal Cáceres province of San Martín region. She devotes her time to the repair and sale of appliance spare parts, especially for computer maintenance. Her shop is located at number 931 in the neighborhood of La Merced, a place to which an ever-increasing number of customers turn each day due to the quality of the workmanship and the parts available. With this six-month loan of $500 (1500 nuevos soles), she will purchase parts and various accessories needed for completing the jobs. It will inspire confidence in the service they provide and most importantly customer satisfaction, which is of paramount importance to her. Marivel is 35 years old, and lives with her husband and two children, who are the impetus that drives her to continue working to give them a better tomorrow. She is a very optimistic woman who in the future longs to expand and refurbish her business premises.

Translated from Spanish by Joyce ., Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of parts and a variety of accessories

loans.name: Joseph Ekow

texts.en: Joseph Ekow G. sells hardware and electrical products at Kormantse near Cape Coast. Joseph Ekow has received a junior high education.  He is married and has 3 children. His wife is a trader. Joseph Ekow has been selling hardware and electrical products since 2004. He is responsible for paying utility bills and school fees. His loan will be used to buy more hardware and electrical products for resale to his ever increasing customer base. He hopes to use the new profits from his business to plough back into the growing business.

loans.use: His loan will be used to buy more hardware and electrical products for resale to his ever increasing costumers.

loans.name: Rin

texts.en:
Rin C. R. is married and has three children, all between 2 and 16 years old. The family lives in the Tboung Khmum district, Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. 
Rin C. R. earns income selling various kinds of groceR. products, while her husband, Lai Phet, is a broker, buying rice crops from the growers and reselling them to vendors at a market. In a typical month, Rin C. R.'s family spends around US$41 on food and US$10 on their two schooling-age children's tuition. To make extra income for the household, Rin C. R. and her husband are now asking for a loan to be able to purchase a couple of pigs for breeding, learning from their neighbors who are already engaged in this type of business.

loans.use: Purchase of pigs for breeding

loans.name: Cecilia Madeleine

texts.en:
Cecilia Madeleine M. Rodriguez is forty years old.  She lives with her husband and her two children in the city of Pucallpa, Peru.  Cecilia’s business is growing and selling plants.  Cecilia is a member of the Las Brisas communal bank and has worked with her group for two years.

Cecilia uses her loans to purchase plant food, pesticides, soil, seeds, seedlings and other plant growing materials.  She is currently requesting a Kiva loan of 2,500 Nuevo Soles to purchase more plants, chemicals and fertilizers.  She will also use the money to rent tools to help her cultivate her plants.  Cecilia appreciates the opportunity to work with more capital and appreciates your support.

loans.use: To purchase more plants, chemicals and fertilizers.

loans.name: Augustina

texts.en:
Augustina M. is twenty-seven years old. She is married and has given birth to four children, all of whom are girls. She says all her daughters are now in basic school. Augustina’s husband is a trader.
